paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation, and can JWST phase-curve data provide evidence for or against an atmosphere-bearing scenario?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: one rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The observed target is a single Earth-sized rocky exoplanet on a short, tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf, observed with JWST MIRI phase-resolved spectroscopy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A theoretical comparison case representing a bare-rock planet with no atmosphere and minimal heat redistribution, serving as the baseline null hypothesis.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A theoretical comparison case representing an atmosphere with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly CO2, with preferred pressure scale 0.3-1.0 bar.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A theoretical comparison case representing an oxidized atmospheric composition with weaker CO2 signature constraints, not fully ruled out by current data.

major_limitations: Single-planet study that does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions including circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
